titleStmt.title: VVestminster Fayre, newly proclaimed. My muse thus venters [sic] to open her ware, and bids you welcome to Westminster Fayre. Wherein, votes, orders, ordinances, this September, are to be sold, with many a rotten Member, a Parliament man; I need say no more: a close committee-man that loves a w- a sequestrator; sure the Devill's not worse then an excise-man, far a greater curse: only a pursuivant, to make hell full, the country poore, the city a meere gull. T'is but a penny, in: too small a fee, to sell you spectacles, these strange sights t'see.
titleStmt.author: Taylor, John, 1580-1653.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 12 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: VVestminster Fayre, newly proclaimed. My muse thus venters [sic] to open her ware, and bids you welcome to Westminster Fayre. Wherein, votes, orders, ordinances, this September, are to be sold, with many a rotten Member, a Parliament man; I need say no more: a close committee-man that loves a w- a sequestrator; sure the Devill's not worse then an excise-man, far a greater curse: only a pursuivant, to make hell full, the country poore, the city a meere gull. T'is but a penny, in: too small a fee, to sell you spectacles, these strange sights t'see.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

lg.l: My Mu≈øe thus venters to open her Ware,
And bids you welcome to We≈øtmin≈øter Fayre.
Votes Orders, Ordinances, this September,
Are to be ≈øold, with many a rotten Member,
A Parliament Man; I need ≈øay no more:
A clo≈øe Committee-man that loves a W‚Äî
A Seque≈øtrator; ≈øure the Devill's not wor≈øe
Then an Exci≈øe man, far a greater cur≈øe:
Only a Pur≈øuivant, to make Hell full,
The Country poore, the City a meere gull.
T'is but a penny, in: too ≈ømall a fee,
To ≈øell you Spectacles, the≈øe ≈øtrange ≈øights t'≈øee.

div.head: We≈øtmin≈øter Fayre.
Sound Drummes and Trumpets.

l.hi: O yes, O yes, O yes, I cry,

div.p:
IT is Decreed and Ordered by the Synod of Divines, a≈ø≈øembled in holy Convocation for the Reformation of Mo≈øes Law, Davids P≈øalmes, the Apo≈øtles Creed, and the New Te≈øtament &c. That this Fayre (now con≈øecrated) ≈øhall foorthwith begin: wherein all their Synodicall con≈øt ‚Ä¢ utions, learned and pious debates, con≈øultations and conclu≈øions, (be≈øides Votes, Ordinances, and Orders) ≈øhall be ≈øet to ≈øale for the pre≈øent payment of the Army, without further delay; and the remayning ≈øummes to be put into a large Che≈øt with 4. Lockes, the Keyes whereof ≈øhall be kept by a Committee of 4. of the holy Synod; viz. by Corah Edwards, Ananias Gouge, Dathan Burges, and Abiram Byfield: and they the ≈øayd Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhall carefully keepe and pre≈øerve all profits ari≈øing from the ≈øayd Fayre, in ≈øale of all the ≈øayd Commodities, heereafter mentioned, for payment of the Army, for tran≈øportation into New England, or Virginia, in ca≈øe the Army will not disband, there to newplant a Presbyterian Nurcery, and to build us ≈øtately Palaces, and buy us all things nece≈ø≈øary for our intended journey. That if we ≈øhall have any remayning gaynes, or ≈øummes, (the premi≈øes
above con≈øidered) that a moyity goe to impeached Members, whether of the Lords or Commons from time to time; that ≈øo they may provide them of all nece≈ø≈øaries to goe with us, the better to effect ≈øo great and pious a Worke, and to goe forward with our Reformation there, which we are not ≈øuffered to fini≈øh here, with all allacrity, joy, and comfort; and for the more ea≈øie comming in of the Countreys to the ‚Ä¢ aid Faire, that all and every the ≈øaid Forts. Fortifications, Halfe-Moones, and Bre≈øt-workes, be ≈øpeedily flung downe and laide levell with the earth and that tho≈øe 4. that keep the ≈øaid Che≈øt before mentioned, ≈øhall not (upon any pretence what≈øoever) open the ≈øame at any time, without there bee foure Earles, three Lards, eight Commons, (provided they be impeached Members) and foure of the mo≈øt grave, ≈øober, wi≈øe and di≈øcreet of the Synod of Divines for the pious u≈øes afore≈øaid.

This Faire was no ≈øooner proclaim'd with great ≈øolemnity (by all the A≈ø≈øembly) but the Boothes, Shopps. and Stalls were pre≈øently furni≈øhed with all manner of Parliament Commodities; as Votes, Orders, Ordinances, New Directories, and all the pretty toyes that the whole body of a Kingdome could devi≈øe.

The fir≈øt Shop I came into, was a faire large Roome with goodly Hangings, ≈øtately ≈øtooles, and at the upper end an empty Chaire richly imbroydered, and two or three at one corner whi≈øpering with wri ‚Ä¢ ings in their hands: I askt what they ≈øold there? pre≈øently one cries out, Who buyes any Bi≈øhops Lands?

lg.l: Come cu≈øtomers, come; her's fertile Earth will yeeld,
As faire a graine as ere was ≈øowne in field:
Heres pa≈øtures, corne, and here are well growne woods:
Her's Bi≈øhops hou≈øes; all their books and goods;
Her's Canterburyes head, empty of braines,
Tak't in your hands, Ile ≈øel't you for ≈ømall gaines.
Her's Altars, Railes, Organ-pipes, and Bellowes,
Pictures of Saints, and other painted fellowes:
Heers Cro≈ø≈øes, Surplices, Miters, and Copes,
Caps, Hoods, and Rochets; be≈øide hempe for Sacrilegious ≈ønares to hang them. ropes.‚Äî
Would you know how to ≈øway the Royall Throne?
Live all like Kings, and make a King like none:
I ≈øell that Art, of all the Devill ere made,
You never ≈øaw more better at the trade.
Come buy new tricks, new juglings, new di≈øclo≈øed,
To teach you how your King ≈øhall be depo≈øed.
Buy a new Covenant, Declaration;
'Tis as good as ever ruin'd Nation.
Buy a new Creed, for two pence that's the price,
'Twill teach you a New way to Paradice.
Buy a new Directory, newly made,
Buy a Scoth brother, now a Reformade:
Buy a gude King, two hundred thou≈øand pounds,
Jockies mu≈øt have, to cure his That the Cavileers gave him, at Mar≈øton moore, where hee run away, and bid the Deele take the hindmo≈øt. mickle wounds.
If you want trea≈øons, or confounding plots,
To ruine Kingdomes, or ou ‚Ä¢ vie the Scots,
Here buy this Plot, and take it on my word,
It is the be≈øt the Devill can afford;
Her's a new Plot to fetch you in more Plate,
And make the Publike Faith renew its ≈øtate.
Come buy this J ‚Ä¢ m; ≈øure it cannot harme ye,
'Twill ≈øtop the mouth of your devouring Army.
Her's a new Stratagem for the City;
Come Fat-heads buy, your han≈øell's very ≈øure,
Advance your ≈øummes, and keep your hands in ure:
Her's ayde for Ireland, ≈øoone ≈øhall quell,
The Rebells there, and ≈øend them all to hell:
That you kinde Cuckolds, may enjoy their land,
And pay the Army that they may disband.
Here is an Witne≈ø≈øe Tomkins, Challoner, and the Kings Me≈ø≈øenger. Ordinance come out to day,
To take your Lives, and your E≈øtates away.
Another too for Tythes, that all mu≈øt pay,
Or el≈øe to Pri≈øon go without delay.
Here is an Ordinance, after all our lo≈ø≈øes,
To be revenged on the harmele≈ø≈øe Cro≈ø≈øes.
Here is another, the more's the pity.
To bani≈øh the Cavaliers from the City.
An Ordinance too, good heaven forbid the banes!
Able to turne their very Sw ‚Ä¢ rds to Kaines:
Another too, a lamentable ≈øtory,
That no man ≈øhall deride the Directory.
Here is another too, ≈øee it I pray‚Äî
To grant the City-brats a Holy day.
With a new trick, to keepe the land in union,
That none but Rebells receive the Communion.
This made the people, when we caus'd the ≈øtirre,
Prophanely call us, Gods of We≈øtmin≈øter.
Then cride another, Sir what will ye buy,
I pray ≈øtep in, and do not ≈øo pa≈ø≈øe by,
Here's a Bunch of Lords impeach'd of Trea≈øon,
Come buy them quickly, while they are in≈øea≈øon.
See for your love, and for your money ‚Ä¢ uy,
Name what you want, Ile fit you pre≈øently:
Buy fairings for your Children, here are toyes,
Fit for your purpo≈øe, be they girles or boyes.
Here's Parliament Ve≈øtments, of all ≈øorts and ≈øizes,
You may have here, at very ea≈øie prizes,
Many a ≈øtorme and ≈øhower they will abide,
Be≈øides a World of knavery they will hide.
Sir looke upon them, view them at your lea≈øure,
The price is ≈ømall, and they'l do you great plea≈øure:
Here is King Pyms robe, th' price not very great,
(And no Excize on't, as he ≈øet on Meate)
Though he hath worn't, it's nere the wor≈øe for wearing,
Girt it but clo≈øe, you need not feare the tearing.
Her's Fa≈øting-dayes (like thinchapt Jackalent)
Shall helpe you at a pinch, when all is ≈øpent;
And her's a new day of Humiliation,
Shall humble all this ≈øorti≈øh Nation.
Her's a new Ordinance, now fetch about,
To fling downe the workes, to let the Cuckow out
Of this new Gottam, that will no more advance
The Souldiers pay; but their owne ignorance.
Another oth' Synod, there ≈øtanding by
With an extended throat, and mouth did cry,
Who buyes the Holy Gho≈øt, pray come away;
Give money quickly, for I cannot ≈øtay.
"What all pa≈ø≈øe by? 'tis ≈øtrange, Time turnes her wheele,
And bends her brow upon us, that wee feel
No han≈øale yet; our Ware's bewitched ≈øure,
And (like our ≈øelves) ther's none will it endure:
Its doom'd to di≈ømall Fate, di≈øpis'd and ≈øcorn'd,
Though nere ≈øo co≈øtly, or ≈øo much adorn'd;
Here's omne vale, yet no money flies,
Our Wares dog-cheape, and thus our credit dies;
For ≈øuch a Faire I never did behold,
Wee bring our Ware, but nothing can be ≈øold.
I wonder cry'd one, what was our intent,
To keepe this Faire ≈øo neare the Parliament;
For wee are mocked here by ≈øancy Jacks,
That bid the Pedlars to put up their packs:
Wee thought our Ware would ≈øell at any price,
And off our hands been vented in a trice;
That this la≈øt Act upon the Engli≈øh Stage,
Would forded money for our Pilgrimage
Unto new England: brethren jog away,
Le≈øt that the Army give us all our pay:
With that a Me≈ø≈øenger came running through th' crowde,
And to the Synod thus he ≈øpake aloud,
To Tyburne or new England chu≈øe you whether,
To one you mu≈øt, you may go altogether;
For all the Lawes oth' Land you have out run,
And I come here to tell you what is done:
The King and the Army will ca≈øt you from your ≈øpheare,
For dire a≈øpects, that you have cau≈øed there,
You are di≈øvoted, and from hence are hurl'd,
To lie like ≈øtars ≈øhot on the lower world.
Your Wares not worth a ≈øart, for all your cogging,
See where the hangman comes, away be jogging,
With that like men of ≈øen≈øes quite bereft,
They trudg'd away, and all this ≈øtuffe they left.
A friend of mine to me did then repaire,
De≈øiring me to write this famous Faire,
Which I have done, and put it here to ≈øell,
Buy then this Faire on me, and ≈øo farewell.

div.p: It is Ordered by the Hou≈øe, that thankes be given to the Author of this learned peece entituled We≈øtmin≈øter Faire, and that it be forthwith printed and publi≈øhed; and that no Pur≈øuivant or other Officer hinder the free ≈øale thereof.

closer.signed: Tho. Tel-treath, Cler, to the abu≈øed Commons.
